importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The government shutdown began on October 1, 2025, triggering the funding crisis for WIC, which had no new appropriations for fiscal year 2026.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from October 1 to October 20, 2025, encompasses the government shutdown and the White House's emergency action to fund WIC using tariff revenue.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration announced that it would redirect Section 32 tariff revenue to fund the WIC program during the government shutdown, instead of using Section 232 tariff revenue.
WIC, which supports nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children, faced a critical funding lapse due to Congress's failure to approve a fiscal year 2026 spending bill.
The National WIC Association welcomed the effort but expressed concern over lack of clarity about funding amounts, timeline, and sustainability.
Legal experts question whether the administration has authority to redirect tariff funds to WIC without congressional appropriation.
Section 232 tariffs, imposed for national security reasons, have generated $190 billion in revenue so far this year, with some funds potentially being reallocated for WIC.
WIC receives capped federal funding; the program had $7.6 billion in FY2025 funding, with a Senate proposal offering $8.2 billion for FY2026.
Enrollment in WIC has increased to nearly 6.9 million, reflecting rising demand due to inflation and improved access.
Bipartisan support for WIC has grown, with Republican leaders like House Speaker Mike Johnson criticizing Democrats for enabling the shutdown.
The White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt announced the tariff-based funding plan on X, framing it as a response to Democratic obstruction.
The Treasury Department manages tariff revenue in a general fund, which is currently frozen without congressional authorization for spending.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive branch of the U.S. government, responsible for policy implementation and crisis management.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House announced a policy shift to fund WIC using tariff revenue during the government shutdown, showing direct executive intervention in social welfare during a political impasse.

namedEntities.name: WIC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children, a federal food assistance program.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is central to the article as it is at risk of shutting down during the government shutdown, highlighting the real-world consequences of political inaction on vulnerable populations.

namedEntities.name: Karoline Leavitt
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: White House press secretary who communicated the tariff funding proposal.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly announced and justified the use of tariff revenue for WIC, framing it as a direct response to congressional obstruction.

namedEntities.name: Section 32 tariff revenue
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariff revenue from Section 32 of U.S. law, traditionally used to support child nutrition programs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This revenue stream is being redirected to fund WIC during the shutdown, marking a strategic reallocation of resources in a crisis.

namedEntities.name: Section 232 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariffs imposed on imported goods on national security grounds.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Originally planned to fund WIC, the administration changed course to use Section 32 revenue, revealing a policy shift in how tariff funds are applied.

namedEntities.name: National WIC Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonprofit organization representing WIC state programs and advocates.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The association raised concerns about transparency and long-term sustainability, underscoring the need for stable, predictable funding.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: House Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He publicly criticized Democrats for causing the shutdown, linking it directly to the suspension of WIC and other federal programs.

namedEntities.name: Chris Towner
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided legal and procedural critique of the administration’s action, highlighting the lack of congressional authorization to redirect funds.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency responsible for administering WIC and food policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It informed states of the funding gap and provided contingency funding, playing a key administrative role in WIC’s crisis management.

namedEntities.name: Senate
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the two chambers of Congress, responsible for passing legislation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Senate's proposed $8.2 billion funding for WIC contrasts with the House’s flat funding, illustrating legislative disagreement over program support.

namedEntities.name: House of Representatives
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the two chambers of Congress, responsible for passing legislation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The House proposed flat funding for WIC, raising concerns about benefit cuts and program instability.

namedEntities.name: Axios
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Media outlet that first reported the White House's tariff funding plan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was the first to report the policy shift, indicating media attention to the political and administrative implications of the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of the United States, who initiated the tariff policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His administration implemented the tariff policy and took executive action to fund WIC, showing the role of political leadership in crisis response.

namedEntities.name: fiscal year 2026
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The annual fiscal period beginning October 1, 2025, which started without federal appropriations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The lack of funding for this fiscal year triggered the WIC crisis, making it a key temporal context.

namedEntities.name: infant formula manufacturers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Companies that produce infant formula, which provide rebates to WIC states.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: States can use rebates from these manufacturers as supplemental funding during the funding gap.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the October 2025 government shutdown, the Trump administration announced it would use Section 32 tariff revenue — traditionally supporting child nutrition programs — to fund the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC), which serves nearly 7 million low-income women and children. The move came after Congress failed to pass a spending bill for fiscal year 2026, threatening to shut down WIC within days. While the National WIC Association welcomed the effort, it emphasized uncertainty around funding amounts, delivery timelines, and long-term sustainability. Legal experts questioned the administration’s authority to redirect funds without congressional authorization. The decision reflects broader political tensions, with Republican leaders blaming Democrats for the shutdown and highlighting bipartisan concern over vulnerable populations. Despite the executive action, advocates stress that long-term stability and adequate funding remain critical for WIC’s continued effectiveness.
title: White House says it will use tariff revenue to fund federal food aid for mothers and young children
